results.title: Fruit flies: an inquiry into behaviour
results.brief_description: Presents biological experiments which show how fruit flies react to changes in environment. Discusses the effect of temperature on reproduction of fruit flies.

results.title: Frozen music
results.brief_description: This film is an examination of the thoughts and aspirations of the Victorian ruling class mentality as revealed through the Albert Memorial, a monument of pure signification. The soundtrack, composed by Michael Nyman, consists of a montage of voices, and is composed of Victorian quotations and modern analyses, together with the bemused speculation of a couple of American tourists.

results.title: From the bottom to the top
results.creator_credit: Jim Berkey, Paul Quinlan, Claire Stapleton and Department of Education Queensland
results.brief_description: The first part of this tape encourages confidence in the water through familiarization, body awareness and movement in the water. The second part presents a natural progression from water activities to swimming skills.

results.title: From one to many: Dvorak's 'Slavic Dance No. 7'
results.brief_description: Excerpt from Bruno Bozzetto’s “Allegro Non Troppo”. An animated comment on social confirmity set to the music of Dvorak. Featuring the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Herbert Von Karajan. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Goering
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Twentieth century”.
Goering’s life story. The air race of 1918; exile in Sweden; return to Germany and the early days of Nazism; Goering sets up the storm troops, the Gestapo, the Luftwaffe, is largely responsible for the economic revival of Germany and wins immense popular prestige. Early Luftwaffe triumphs are eclipsed by the failure of operation Sea Lion and the RAAF raids on Germany. Goering falls from power and public prestige to a figurehead. His capture, trial and sentence at Nuremberg.

results.title: Gandhi
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Twentieth century”.
Traces Gandhi’s rise to power in India and his struggles to win independence for his country, terminating in his assassination on January 30, 1948. Narrated by Walter Cronkite.

results.title: Victory over polio
results.creator_credit: McGraw-Hill Films and Columbia Broadcasting System
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Twentieth century”.
The history of polio and its treatment and the discovery of the Salk vaccine. Old newsreels show the late President Roosevelt in the early stages of treatment at the Georgia Retreat, and Sister Kenny at work. Some of the medical men who have worked on the disease and the final triumph by Dr. Jonas E. Salk.

results.title: Movies learn to talk
results.creator_credit: Burton Benjamin, Kenco Films, Columbia Broadcasting System and Prudential Insurance Company of America
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Twentieth century”.
Traces the development of sound movies from early experiments with clumsy systems at the turn of the century to “The Jazz Singer” in 1927 and the polished and sophisticated sound film of today. Includes glimpses of film personalities and excerpts from silent and sound movies. Narrated by Walter Cronkite.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Burton Benjamin, Kenco Films, Columbia Broadcasting System and Prudential Insurance Company of America

results.title: War in Spain
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Twentieth century”.
Traces the course of the Spanish Civil War, its outbreak, the intervention of outside powers for their own ends, and the final defeat of the loyalist government by Franco and his Falange.

results.title: The Week that shook the world
results.creator_credit: Isaac Kleinerman, Burton Benjamin and Columbia Broadcasting System
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Twentieth century”.
Traces the day by day events of the historic week in which Europe tottered on the brink of World War II. The week from the end of August and the beginning of September 1939 - the last peaceful days the world was to know for six years. It ended with Hitler’s blitzkrieg into Poland, eleven months after British Prime Minister Chamberlain’s “peace in our time” declaration followed the Munich Pact. Narrated by Walter Cronkite.
